Award.AwardTitle: CC* Network Design and Implementation for Small Institutions: The Tommie Science Network- A dedicated research network for the University of St. Thomas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of St. Thomas, in conjunction with the University of Minnesota's Gopher Science Network Team, is building the Tommie Science Network, a dedicated research network that transforms the campus research environment by providing a reliable and secure high-speed research network capable of achieving sustained transmission rates of up to 100 Gigabits per second (Gbps) between campus research locations and Internet2 (I2). This project creates efficiencies in end-to-end workflows between existing instrumentation facilities and research centers, centralized computing and data storage facilities, and partner institutions. It significantly increases bandwidth available to researchers, allowing the St. Thomas community to fully participate in collaborative, global research activity, and provides a world-class working environment for professors and students to practice distributed research and collaboration techniques to learn skills they will use in their future employment.

The Tommie Science Network connects Owens Science Hall, O'Shaughnessy Science Hall and the St. Thomas E-learning and Research center (STELAR) via high-speed access layer switches linked to the network core at 80Gbps. Traffic on the Tommie Science Network then bypasses the firewall to connect directly to I2 at 100Gbps via the Northern Lights Gigapop. Laboratories and research locations in the science halls and STELAR are connected at 10Gbps to the access layer switches. Globus File Transfer Protocol is used to allow secure, reliable high-speed transfers between the science buildings, the DMZ, and I2. PerfSonar is used to monitor performance between the science buildings and the and Science Demilitarized Zone (Science DMZ) as well as from the DMZ to Internet2. The St. Thomas networking staff is responsible for ongoing operations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has afforded St. Thomas the opportunity to increase our overall research and educational outreach capabilities significantly. The High Speed Research Network/Science DMZ put in place during this project has helped us to achieve parity with larger universities in terms of research networking speeds, capacity, and interconnection, providing opportunities for research, recruitment, collaboration, outreach, education and training.

 Prior to the implementation of this network, St. Thomas researchers were limited to 2gbps of bandwidth, internally and to the Internet. With the HSRN in service, speeds to the Internet are now 100gbps with up to 40gbps directly to research locations on campus, allowing researchers the scope to envision and implement research programs and studies that were previously impossible. The HSRN also provides St. Thomas the opportunity to recruit world-class researchers, ensuring that that will have the ability to seamlessly transition their studies and offering assurance that future research will be supported by a dedicated, modern research network environment. Students are benefitting from the HSRN through expanded support and access for their own research, as well as through exposure to a standardized research network environment similar to those they will encounter at R1 universities and within private industry.

Academic Computing and Campus Networking have forged stronger ties throughout this project as they worked together to build an environment that adhered to institutional support requirements while ensuring that researcher needs and ease-of-use remained at the forefront. The collaborative effort between the two groups has created a stronger bond and consistent working relationship that will yield benefits beyond the immediate project, creating common ground and a working process that will persist into the future. Our collaborative ties with the University of Minnesota also grew stronger throughout this project. The UoM networking team is well established and very knowledgeable, serving as mentors throughout the project and as a constant source of advice and assistance. This project is an excellent example of a private/public collaboration, and the cooperation and willingness of the UofM collaborate with St. Thomas has resulted in an ongoing partnership around research networking and beyond that has allowed St. Thomas to achieve a system that would not have been possible without the connections, expertise and collaboration of the UofM personnel.

 The Digital Humanities has seen a significant rise at St. Thomas, partly due to the HSRN as well as through our Digital Humanities Grant Program. The infrastructure we have developed allows non-technical researchers to partner with programmers, technical administrators and a project manager, allowing them to focus on their domain expertise while using equipment and techniques that might have too high a technical barrier to otherwise consider. The Digital Humanities have become a key focus of the College of Arts and Sciences and the university, and the program has already sponsored and executed many projects that would not have moved beyond the conceptual stage in the previous environment.

While the project generally ran smoothly over the project period, several issues did arise. Vendor confusion over the infrastructure was one area that caused delay. General network vendors unfamiliar with research networks had a hard time understanding the design, and attempted to place the network behind the firewall! We lost the key technical person on the St. Thomas side partway through the project, which caused some delay as the new person got up to speed. Covid-19 hit during the last year of the project, although we were well enough into it that we had a solid design and were able to move forward without too much trouble other than scheduling difficulties.

Overall, this project was well executed, issues were handled without significant trouble, and the outcome has positioned St. Thomas to move forward with the expansion of research capability across all academic areas and out into the larger world of research and collaboration. It was a great project to be a part of, and the internal and external partnerships it has fostered will benefit St. Thomas far beyond the project period. Thanks to the National Science Foundation, the University of Minnesota and internal St. Thomas faculty and staff from Networking, Academic Computing, the sciences and the humanities for a wonderful partnership and the opportunity for ongoing collaboration!
